A.proverb: Agikuyu moi kuhitha ndia, matiui kuhitha uhoro.
A.translation: The Kikuyu know how to conceal their quiver, but donot know how to conceal their secrets.
A.note: The Kikuyu, though very clever in concealing their arms, cannot keep secrets from the members of their tribe.

A.translation: Two guests (at the same time) have no welcome.
Two guests love a different song.
A.note: When you receive two visitors at the same time, you cannot treat them in the same manner because they have different tastes.
A.equivalent: Every man has his hobby horse.

A.translation: He is a man that looks after many as ‘njuu’ looks after locusts.
A.note: 'Njuu' is a bird which accompanies migrating locusts to feed on them

A.proverb: Aka eri ni nyungu igiri cia urogi.
A.translation: Two wives are two pots full of poison
A.note: The more women you have in your house, the more troubles you must expect.

A.proverb: Aka matiri cia ndiiro no cia nyiniko.
A.translation: Women have no upright words, but only crooked ones.
A.note: The Kikuyu use the proverb to say that women keep no secrets and seldom tell the truth.
A.equivalent: Women conceal all that they know not.

A.translation: Wives and oxen have no friends.
A.note: There are things which are not to be given to friends.
A.equivalent: A woman is to be from her house three times: when she is christened, married, and buried.

A.translation: People who have not secret agreement are beaten by a single club.
A.note: One can notice a difference between man and man when they, ‘exemplify Gratia’ are commanding or working, but not on the road where they look quite the same.

A.proverb: Andu matari ndundu mahuragwo na njuguma imwe.
A.translation: People who have not secret agreement are beaten by a single club.
A.note: A group of men not bound by a secret will be easily beaten by a single man.
One does not give without hope of return.

A.translation: Me do not know hard firewood, but only lops.
A.note: People put aside hard tasks and devote themselves only to easy ones.

A.translation: Live men do not lack work
A.equivalent: Life would be too smooth if it had no rubs in it.

A.translation: He who seeks his goat with the man who ate it, is certain not to find it.
A.note: Do not look for stolen goods in the robber’s house.
Do not annoy others because they will respond by hurting.
A.equivalent: Do evil and look for like.

B.equivalent: He that will have no trouble in this world must not be born in it.

C.translation: The elders drink afterwards (i.e after the others).
C.note: Elderly people are not in such a hurry as young ones.

C.translation: The food found Wacu in the field.
C.note: The proverb originates in the legend of Wacu, the most despised amongst the wives of a rich man who never gave her any presents. One day, when a banquet was being held at home, she went to work in the field, since she knew there would be nothing for her at home. In the middle of the banquet a raven swooped down in the courtyard where the meat was being roasted, snatched a big piece and brought it to Wacu. The Kikuyu use the proverb to say that God takes care of His poor.

C.translation: The property of a helpless man must nit be divided before his death.
C.note: The reason is that he is unable to get anything more than he already possesses.

C.proverb: Cia mucii iri gacuguma gacio gatathukagio ni muthuri ungi tiga mweneguo
C.translation: Home affairs have their staff, which cannot be brandished by anyone but the head of the house.
C.note: The proverb means either that private matters must not be spoken of to strangers or that in each house there must be only one in authority.

C.translation: Home affairs must not go into the open.
C.equivalent: Do not wash dirty linen in public

C.translation: Home affairs cannot be told to the public.
C.equivalent: Do not wash dirty linen in public.

C.translation: The widow’s sons have not tears.
C.note: It means that they have been accustomed to suffer very early.

C.translation: Birds agree when flying down, but do not agree when flying up.
C.equivalent: The proverb means that it is easy for a swarm of birds to alight together, while it is difficult to get up together since after eating their fill they will fly up separately. Morally the proverb means that men easily agree when deciding on an enterprise, but will probably quarrel as soon as they have obtained what they want.

C.translation: Bought things do not fill the granary.
C.note: Do not hope to become rich without cultivating your fields.

C.translation: When there is shortage of figs, birds eat the fruits of the ‘mugumo’.
C.note: The tree called ‘mugumo’ by the natives bears little fruits that are not eated by birds when there is plenty of other food.
C.equivalent: If thou hast not a capon, feed on an onion.

C.translation: The buying of a wife begins from a little thing.
Goats fall that take hold of lichens.
C.note: Lichens are not strong enough to prevent a goat from falling. The proverb means that unsatisfactory excuses are insufficient defence.

C.proverb: Cionje ikumi irugitwo ni umwe uri na hinya
C.translation: Ten helpless people were surpassed by a single strong person.
C.note: One strong person is better than ten helpless ones.
C.equivalent: One grain of pepper is worth a cartload of hail.
Fools and obstinate men make lawyers rich.

C.proverb: Cira munene ni wa uthoni ugikua
C.translation: The breaking of a betrothal is no small matter.
C.note: Marrying a girls means giving a large number of goats or cattle to her family. Starting from the day of the betrothal the price is paid gradually. Evidently it is no simple matter if the would-be husband breaks his contract and demands the return of the marriage price.

C.translation: The lawsuit of a fool keeps the court (sitting) all day.
C.equivalent: The lawsuit of a fool never comes to an end.

C.translation: Home affairs are not to be carried on in the public squuare.
C.equivalent: Do not wash dirty linen in public.

C.translation: Every case begins from the stomach.
C.note: The Kikuyu have an ox or a goat killed, roasted and distributed to judges at the beginning of every case. Familiarly they use the proverb to say that one of the most important jobs of life is to provide something to eat.

C.translation: We speak by proverbs: he who is intelligent will understand.

E.note: ‘Thakirio’ is the place the Kikuyu hut where the wife stays when distributing the food to the family.

G.translation: He who spends his time adorning himself knows he is going to a dance.
G.equivalent: There is a reason for everything.

G.translation: He who adorns himself knows to what sort of dance he is going.
G.equivalent: There is a reason for everything.

G.translation: The fool takes many people with him.
G.note: It is said of people who, when invited to a feast, instead of going alone, take others with them.
G.equivalent: A fool cannot bear his own company.

G.proverb: Garurira mbeu ti ya kinya kimwe
G.translation: Change seeds taking them from different calabashes.
G.equivalent: It is good to introduce new blood.

G.proverb: Gatami kari mondo yene gatingikuratira nguo
G.translation: The piece of cloth that is in another’s bag does not patch your garment.
A little, contemptible path is sometimes the one that leads you to the highway.
G.equivalent: Little strokes fell great oaks.

G.proverb: Gatitu ka muimwo ni iri noko kari miti
G.translation: The forest of an unpleasant (ill-liked) person is the one that has trees.
G.note: The proverb means that evil-doers often do prosper.

G.translation: The grove of the hear is not laid open.
Nobody cries that has not been pinched.
G.equivalent: No smoke without fire.

G.translation: Darkness caused to dance even him who cannot.
G.equivalent: All cats are the same in colour at night.

G.translation: A secret agreement enabled people to kill Watatua. Contextual note: Watatua was a powerful Chief, invincible in open     combat, who was killed at night by a few men.
G.equivalent: Secret union means strength.

G.translation: A market can be spoiled by one woman.
G.equivalent: One cloud is enough to eclipse the sun.

G.translation: Every feast has its guest of honor.
One appointment is eaten by another.
G.equivalent: Today kills yesterday.

G.translation: That of circumcision is a hard appointment.
G.note: The Kikuyu circumcision is a civil and religious rite by which the adolescent is admitted into the public life of the tribe and becomes a man in the full possession of his rights. The ceremony is physically painful, but the candidate is expected to face the operationwithout wincing.

G.proverb: There are not gains without pains.
G.translation: To wait is not to tremble.
G.equivalent: Men's actions are not to be judged at first sight.

G.proverb: Gicegu kia andu aingi ti kiega
G.translation: The 'gicegu' of many men is not good.
G.note: ‘Gicegu’ is that part of the Kikuyu hut where they enclose the ram in order to fatten it.
G.equivalent: Too many cooks spoil the broth.

G.proverb: A piece of land is not a little thing.
G.translation: The proverb means that however small the field you possess, it has its importance if you work it.
G.equivalent: A little house well filled, a little land well tilled, a little wife well willed are great riches.

G.proverb: Giikaro kimwe kiri ngee kana ndaa
G.translation: By staying always in the same place one gets lice.
G.equivalent: The world is a great book, of which they that never stir from home read only one page.

G.translation: The only thing good, though old, is the 'muratina'.
G.note: ‘Muratina’ is the fruit of the hot-dog tree (Kigelia Etiopica) used by the natives to cause fermentation of sugar-cane beer. It is believed that the older the fruit, the greater it is fermenting power. The proverb means that there are only few things that improve with age.

G.translation: You cannot (do not) make an appointment with death.
The land enriches not people who clear it, but peoplewho come (when it is already cleared).
G.equivalent: One beats the bush, and another catches the bird.

G.translation: Lying is the thief’s stronghold.
Beggars have no worries.
G.equivalent: Poverty needs no granary.

G.translation: The chest contains a beehive full of pride.
G.note: The proverb means that proud people have always in store lots of reasons justifying their wickedness.

G.translation: Talking something over is better than leaving it pending.
G.equivalent: Never leave that till tomorrow which you can do today.

G.proverb: Gitiiro kia muka wene gitikagio athii
G.translation: The song of a stranger-woman is answered after she has gone.
G.note: The proverb is metaphorically used to mean that foreigners, especially women, are not to be trusted too much.
G.equivalent: Eat a peck of salt with a man before you trust him.

G.translation: It is bad to stay at home.
G.equivalent: He that stays in the valley shall never get over the hill.

G.translation: He who does not know, knows after being told.
G.equivalent: A man forewarned is forearmed.

G.translation: He who does not know the road delays also one that knows it.
G.equivalent: Who goes with a fool becomes a fool.

G.translation: The rich man cannot be prevented from cultivating the ‘iganjo’ he wants.
G.note: ‘Iganjo’ is the place upon which a hut had been built. Since the flocks live in the owner’s hut, the floor of the hut becomes fertilized. The proverb refers to the fact that if a rich man has left a piece of his land to a poor man on which to build his hut, very often he wants it back as soon as the soil under the hut has been enriched by the dropping of the animals.
G.equivalent: Mights is right.

G.translation: Rich people sometimes eat bad food.
G.equivalent: All is not gold that glitters.

G.translation: Traveling is learning.
G.equivalent: The world is a great book, of which they that never stir read only one page.

G.translation: To be slim does not mean having been pared
G.equivalent: Do not scorn little things.

G.translation: The woman who gives birth to a child is like the banana tree that breaks under the weight of its fruit.
G.equivalent: Maternity means pain to the mother.

G.proverb: Guciara uru ti kwenda kwa mwene
G.translation: It is not the mother’s will to have a bad offspring.
People slander somebody even if they do not despise him.
Riches and poverty do not leave each other.
To keep one’s tongue is worthy of praise.
G.equivalent: Silence is golden.

G.translation: Not to talk is to hate.
G.equivalent: One keeps silence with people one does not like.

G.translation: Indulgence breeds regret.

G.proverb: Gukura ni kuuru: ngathii uriri ngicayaga
G.translation: It is bad to get old, for one goes to bed grumbling.
G.equivalent: Old sacks want much patching.

G.translation: The fact that you have gone near the battle-field does not mean that you fought.
Thieves conceal themselves in the night not in the day.
G.equivalent: The night is a cloak for sinners.

G.translation: To get the warmth of fire one must stir the embers.
G.equivalent: No gains without pains.

G.translation: The fear (of toil) keeps your house poor.
G.equivalent: Idleness is the key of beggary.

G.translation: If you help yourself you will be helped.
G.equivalent: God helps those who help themselves.

G.proverb: Gutema na kanua ti gitema na ruhiu
G.translation: Cutting by the tongue is different from cutting by the knife.
G.note: Slander is not mortal stabbing.
G.equivalent: Hard words break no bones.

G.translation: A man changing his abode is like a woman marrying.
G.note: As a woman, on marrying, adopts the customs of the family she enters, so a man going to live in a strange country, must accept its customs.
G.equivalent: When in Rome do as Rome does.

G.proverb: Guthekererwo ni andu ti kuririrwo ni hiti
G.translation: To be laughed at by men is not to be wept by hyenas.
G.note: Better to be laughed at than to die.

G.translation: To be laughed at is not to be pitied.
G.note: One starting any enterprise ought not to fear what others say of him.
G.equivalent: Do well and dread no shame.

G.translation: If anybody makes you laugh, it is not always because he loves you.
G.equivalent: Eat a peck of salt with a man before you trust him.

G.translation: Some hope for rain even though they have not prepared their fields.
G.note: He who hopes for favours should have prepared himselfto profit by them.

G.translation: To go does not prevent a man from returning.
G.equivalent: Never give up.

G.translation: Travelling teaches men their way.
Travelling is seeing.
G.equivalent: ravel broadens the mind.

G.translation: Having rain clouds is not the same as having rain.
G.equivalent: Don’t cry herrings till they are in the net.

G.translation: Virtue is better than riches.
G.equivalent: Virtue is the only true nobility.

G.translation: Virtue is power.
G.equivalent: Virtue makes men on the earth famous, in their graves illustrious, in the heaven immortal.

G.proverb: Guthura ng’ombe ni guthura kamukwa kayo
G.translation: To despise the ox means to despise also a strip of hide from it.
G.note: One cannot scorn great things without scorning little ones related to them.

G.translation: One favours him from whom one has in the past received a gift.
G.equivalent: One good turn deserves another.

G.translation: A man is (sometimes) scorned who will be loved (later on).
G.equivalent: Judge not of men or things at first sight.

G.translation: here is no thing which does not cause another to exist.
There is no butcher that does not slaughter.
G.equivalent: Every man to his trade.

G.translation: One ages every night one lives.
G.equivalent: Time fleeth away without delay.

G.proverb: Gutiri ita ithiagwwo na gitete kia njohi no gia ucuru
G.translation: No war has been fought by men carrying a calabash of ‘njohi’ but of ‘ucuru’.
G.note: ‘Njohi’ is an inebriating drink brewed out of sugar-cane.‘Ucuru’ is a kind of thin porridge made by boiling millet-flour in water. This gruel is supposed to be highly nourishing and therefore suitable for long journeys or hard fighting; while the sugar-cane beer by inebriating the                warriors makes them weak and easy prey to the enemy.
G.equivalent: Out of temperance comes strength.

G.proverb: Gutiri mbura itari na gitonga kiayo
G.translation: There is no rain which does not enrich someone.
G.equivalent: It is an ill wind that blows nobody good.

G.proverb: Gutiri mucii uri kahii utakarugwo mutwe
G.translation: In every family where there is a son, the head of an ox, goat or ram is cooked to be eaten by him with his friends.
G.note: They use the proverb to mean that ordinarily a son gives his parent more trouble than a daughter, or that in every family parents do not lack troubles.
G.equivalent: There is a black sheep in every family.

G.translation: here is no difference between the thief and the looker-on.
Nobody entering a hut pays for the heart he will enjoy in it.
G.note: Only the owner of the hut had the drudgery of carrying home the firewood; the visitor does not know the cost of the fire he is enjoying. Metaphorically the proverb is used to say that he who enters a house cannot realise the troubles of the occupants.
G.equivalent: None knows the weight of another’s burden.

G.proverb: Gutiri mundu ui haria eguthii no haria ekuuma
G.translation: Nobody knows where he goes, but only whence he comes.
G.equivalent: No one can see into the future.

G.proverb: Gutiri mundu wendaga gutungana na nyoni njuru
G.translation: Nobody wants to meet an ill-omened bird
G.note: To the Kikuyu many birds foreshadow calamity. The cry of the owl forebodes mishap. If the owl cries, perched on the top of a hut, the oldest man in that village will die very soon. If someone, about to make a journey, hears the cry of any bird of ill- omen, he must not start on any account.
G.equivalent: Nobody seeks his own ruin.

G.translation: There is no man that cannot become an orpha
G.equivalent: No flying from fate.

G.proverb: Gutiri mundu wonaga wega wake, no kuonwo wonagwo
G.translation: Nobody can see his own goodness: it can be seen only by others.
There is no pleasure (however little it may be) that does not cause one’s cheeks to tremble.
G.note: The Kikuyu consider the cheek trembling an expression of joy.
G.equivalent: A little pleasure is nertheless a pleasure

G.translation: No day dawns like another.
G.equivalent: Every day brings a new light.

G.proverb: Gutiri mutumia wenjagirwo mbui kwa nyina
G.translation: No married woman will have her white hair shaved at her mother's.
G.note: The Kikuyu girls go around with bald heads which they get periodically shaved by their relations. So the woman, who by being married has left her house and relations, will never be shaved at her mother's.
G.equivalent: Once sold, ever sold.

G.translation: The son does not cut his finger in cutting meat for his father.
G.equivalent: Sons are stingier than their parents.

G.translation: There is no partridge which does not know its own way of scratching.
G.equivalent: As many methods as men.

G.translation: No partridge is small when it claws the soil.
G.equivalent: Every one can do great good or evil according to his possibilities.

G.translation: No prepotent man will insult other people for two consecutive seasons.
G.note: Prepotence comes quickly to an end.

G.translation: Meat has no choice morsel.
G.note: When distributing the meat or anything else one must not favour any one person.

G.translation: There is no nice bird in the millet.
G.note: Millet is one of the staple crops of the Kikuyu. They protect it from birds by building pulpit-like huts in which boys or women stand to frighten them whilst the harvest is ripening.
G.equivalent: Even sugar itself may spoil a good dish.

G.translation: Nobody is born wise.
Nobody returns where he got his finger bitten.
G.equivalent: Once bitten twice shy.

G.proverb: Gutiri uikagia itimu atari na haria akuratha
G.translation: Nobody throws a lance if he has no target.
G.equivalent: There is a reason for everything.

G.translation: Nobody walks with another man’s gait.
G.equivalent: Every man in his way.

G.translation: There is nothing without a cause.
G.note: All things have a beginning.

G.translation: Nobody grumbles at being rich, all at being poor.

G.proverb: Gutiri uriragio ni utonga no ukia
G.translation: Nobody cares about other people’s poverty.
There is no mischance you are guaranteed against.
G.equivalent: There is many a slip ‘twixt the cup and the lip.

G.proverb: Gutiri uru utuuraga, no wega utuuraga
G.translation: No evil, but only the good will last.
G.equivalent: Good deeds remain, all things else perish.

G.translation: There is no bow without its meat.
G.equivalent: God helps those who help themselves.

G.translation: There is no name which cannot distinguish a child.
G.equivalent: Every bird is known by its feathers.

G.translation: There is no location which discusses its affairs in the same way as the other does.
G.equivalent: Every man in his way.

G.translation: A man is poor not because he scorns possessions, but because he possesses nothing.
G.equivalent: Sour grapes, as the fox said when he could not reach them.

G.proverb: Gutiri wa nda na wa mugongo
G.translation: There is not the son of the front and the son of the back.
G.note: The Kikuyu mothers carry a baby on the back if they have only one. If they have two, one is carried in front and the other one on the back. Of course the one carried near the breasts can suck oftener than the other. That is why they say this is the favourite one.
G.equivalent: Parents should have no Benjamin.

G.proverb: Gutiri wiriraga agikuua, eriraga akiiga thi
G.translation: Nobody grumbles while carrying a load, but when he has laid it down.
G.note: The proverb means that nobody hates to be rich but all hate to become poor; or that nobody refuses to command, though all are sorry when they have to give up the command.

G.translation: Everybody regrets not what he leaves but what he does not find (when he comes back).

G.proverb: Gutiri witaga ithe wa ungi baba
G.translation: Nobody calls another’s father ‘dad’.
To forget a strong man who could help you is the same as to scorn him.
To forget is the same as to throw away.
The man that serves is not prevented from being served in turn.
G.equivalent: Every dog has its day, and every man his hour.

G.translation: The day is for working, the night is for resting.
G.equivalent: There is a time to wink as well as to see.

G.translation: To seek a woman to the belly.
G.note: The expression is used when they look for something to eat. To go foraging.

G.translation: Some soldiers are only soldiers when talking.
G.equivalent: A good friend is a treasure.

G.translation: A good action reaps another.
G.equivalent: One good turn deserves another.

H.proverb: Handu ha njuguma na ha mugwi hatiganaine
H.translation: The place to use the club and the above arrow are not the same.
In the presence of elderly people one must not pour water.
H.note: Nobody is allowed to be foul-mouthed especially when elderly people are present.

H.proverb: Haro ni ya muka uri ihii
H.translation: Quarrelling is peculiar to the woman who has got male children.
H.note: They use the proverb to mean that since sons are more mischievous than daughters, and mothers are more proud of their sons than of their daughters, women are inclined to quarrel to defend or to exalt their sons.
H.equivalent: No mother is so wicked but desires to have good children.

H.proverb: Haro ni ya muka uri thiri
H.translation: Quarrelling is peculiar to the woman who has debts.
H.note: A woman in debt is quarrelsome.

H.equivalent: Small faults indulged are little thieves that let in great.

H.translation: A wily person does not walk on dry leaves (for they would betray his presence).
Strength does not correspond with courage.

H.note: Strong people are not necessarily rich people.

H.translation: When hyenas go away jackals rejoice.
H.equivalent: Little dogs begin to eat when big ones have eaten enough.

H.proverb: Hiti itaga iria ingi ya mutiri
H.translation: The hyena calls another hyena worse than itself.
H.equivalent: The pot calling the kettle black.

H.proverb: Hiti yugaga arume ni ogi, monaga gicinga ngwatiro
H.translation: Hyena says that men are wise because they know how to hold a firebrand.
H.note: A story told by the Kikuyu says that one night a hyena entered a hut to eat the goats. The owner wakened by the noise, took hold of a firebrand to scare it out. The beast tried top do the same, but not knowing how to handle firebrands it scorched its paws.
H.equivalent: There is a right and a wrong way of doing everything.

H.proverb: Hiti ndiriaga mwana, na mui uria iri ngoroku
H.translation: The hyena does not eat its baby, and you know how insatiable it is.
H.equivalent: No mother is so wicked but loves her children.

H.translation: Vultures arrive at the place where the goat is slaughtered.
H.equivalent: Where the carcase is, the ravens will gather.

H.proverb: Hungu igithii iguru ndiatigire thi kuri kwega
H.translation: The vulture perches on the trees because it does not feel sure on the ground.
To eat much leaves you with a swollen belly.
H.equivalent: Enough is as good as a feast.

H.translation: The abyss laughs at the plain.
H.equivalent: Every man thinks his own geese swans.

I.translation: The cow has a bad delivery though her owner is present.
I.equivalent: Misfortunes may come in spite of watchfulness.

I.translation: Iganagwo yaari iria yakua
I.equivalent: A friend is never known till needed.

I.translation: The cow is given a present when her calf is carried away.
I.equivalent: When one thing distresses you, another consoles you.

I.translation: The ox that claws the ‘kiara’ will die.
I.note: ‘Kiara’ is the dunghill you will find in every Kikuyuvillage. In order to understand the proverb it much be borne in mind that the Kikuyu regard it as a sacred place which the witch-doctors dedicates with the sacrifice of a goat to secure that the evil spirits may not return into the hut from which he expelled them. They are supposed to stay in the ‘kiara’ just as the rubbish does.
I.equivalent: Touch pitch and you’ll be defiled.

I.translation: The ox that feeds itself does not spoil its skin.
The animal rambling in the stable makes the sleeping ones rise too.
I.equivalent: Ill examples are like contagious diseases.

I.translation: The ram that is shown around is not fat.
I.note: A really fat ram will easily find a buyer and does not need to be carried around and shown in the markets.
I.equivalent: Good ware makes a quick market.

I.translation: The cimex lives in the firewood and still it reaches its full growth.
I.equivalent: Where there is a will there is a way.

I.proverb: Iri giciarira riua-ini yongithagiria o ho
I.translation: he cow that drops her calf in the sun feeds it there too.
I.equivalent: One likes the place where one does well.

I.proverb: Iri gukura iriagwo iguku ni aka
I.translation: The hump of the ox that has grown old must be eaten by women.
I.note: The hump is a choice morsel for young men when the ox is young. But if it is old women must eat it.
I.equivalent: Rubbish is women’s portion.

I.translation: The ox which has grown old has no admirer.
I.equivalent: Nobody looks after elderly people.

I.translation: The flea troubles him who has got it in his ear.
Nobody gathers firewood to roast a thin goat.
I.equivalent: Poor people have no friends.

I.translation: There is no tree which a panting animal would not cling to.
I.equivalent: A drowning man will catch at a straw.

I.translation: The ox that ran away cannot be caught.
I.equivalent: Resist the beginnings.

I.proverb: Iri kuruga ni iguita, iguitirira ni nguu
I.translation: The cooking pot on the fire leaks, when pouring water it is broken.
I.equivalent: Misfortunes come by forties.

I.translation: The ox which has no horns, relies for help on the one that has them.
I.note: He who feels weak relies on the friend he knows is strong.

I.proverb: Iri muthece kinya tene ndioyagira ingi
I.translation: The bird who has always possessed a beak, does not pick up for another.
I.equivalent: Content is more than a kingdom.

I.proverb: Iri nyite ni mutego ndithuire gwiteithura
I.translation: The animal caught in the trap does not refuse to set itself free.
I.equivalent: No man likes his fetters, though of gold.

I.translation: It is he who got milk that is merciful.
I.note: ‘Milk’ here has the sense of money; possessions. The proverb means that the rich should help needy people, since the poor cannot do it.

I.translation: The timid ox drinks muddy water.
I.note: He goes to the river only when others have come away leaving the water dirty.
I.equivalent: Faint heart never won fair lady.

I.translation: He who goes around with his body upright, later on will go crawling.
I.equivalent: Young today, old tomorrow.

I.translation: To blame the wind for the rain that does not fall.
I.note: It refers to boasting people who try to make silly excuses for themselves.

I.proverb: Itari thahu igunagwo ni makoro ma njira
I.translation: The man who has no impurity will be helped even by the peels he sees on the road.
I.note: There are many ways by which a Kikuyu can contract impurity and he fears the baneful effects which will follow it. That is why a man able to avoid all legal unclanness is said to be so lucky.
I.equivalent: God helps honest people.

I.translation: The goat slaughtered for a man who is sick now, finds another who ws sick long before.
I.equivalent: God cures and the doctor takes the fee.

I.translation: The sky is heavy with rain, but does not come.
I.note: It refers to people who are always promising great thing which they never do.
I.equivalent: Great boast, small roast.

I.translation: A plant loses its blossom as soon as it bears fruit.
I.note: Woman’s beauty is spoilt by maternity.

I.proverb: Igai ria mutundu ritigiragia kiriti kiunwo
I.translation: A branch of ‘mutundu’ does not hinder the division of a field.
I.note: ‘Mutundu’ is a small tree growing in the bush. It is not used by the natives, except as firewood.

I.translation: The tooth laughs with the lance.
I.note: It means that oftern a person plays with his enemy.
I.equivalent: The cat plays with the mouse.

I.translation: Young sugar-cane gives no beer.
I.equivalent: There is no putting old heads on young shoulders.

I.translation: Great haste breaks the yam tuber (instead of taking it out whole).
I.equivalent: Haste trips up its own heels.

I.translation: Boys and sugar-cane grow up as enemies (because boys are all the time eating sugar-cane).

I.proverb: Ihiga riega ritiringanaga na thio njega
I.translation: A good millstone does not meet a good miller.
The foot and the earth cannot help meeting.
Old people’s walking teaches young ones to walk.
I.equivalent: That comes of a cat will catch mice.

I.translation: One can lose four and eight
I.equivalent: All covet all lose.

I.translation: Stolen things bring in misfortune.
I.equivalent: Ill gotten goods seldom prosper.

I.translation: Riches are found in cultivating together.
I.equivalent: Many hands make light work.

I.proverb: Iriaga na mbugi kuri na ugwati
I.translation: The goats pasture with bells hanging from their necks in order not to stray.
If the first goat goes lame, those that follow will not reach the pasture.
I.equivalent: Ill examples are like contagious diseases.

I.translation: Candidates for circumcision after washing do not return to warm themselves at their father’s (but go straightaway to the place of the ceremony to show their courage).
I.equivalent: In things that must be it is good to be resolute.

I.translation: The food that is in the mouth is not yet in the belly.
I.equivalent: Do not cry herrings till they are in the net.

I.translation: When the food is cooked there is no need to wait before eating it.
What is in Masai is not in Kikuyu.
I.equivalent: There is many a slip ‘twixt the cup and the lip.

I.translation: The pit allows the grass to fall in.
I.note: The proverb alludes to the pits the Kikuyu used to dig for trapping wild animals. These pits were covered with sticks over which, as well as over borders, they put a layer of grass. Since this grass often fell in the pit through the spaces between the sticks, so they say that often one falls into the pit dug by himself.
I.equivalent: Hoist with his own petard

I.translation: Fools rejoice for a bad thing.
I.equivalent: A fool will laugh when he is drowning.

I.translation: Cooked food is not sold for goats (but is given to friends visitors and pilgrims).
I.equivalent: God helps the poor for the rich can help themselves.

I.translation: The war of the eyes never comes to an end.
I.equivalent: The eye is never satisfied with seeing.

I.translation: The war that has no unity will make no prey.
Other’s ornaments tire one’s neck.
I.equivalent: Do not wear borrowed plumes.

I.translation: When ‘ithare’ is uprooted ‘mugumo’ grows in its place.
I.note: ‘Ithare’ is a kind of a cane growing on the riverbanks. The Kikuyu say it is of no use. ‘Mugumo’ is a kind of a fig tree (Ficus Hochstetteri), which does not grow except leaning on another tree or twisting around it like a creeper. This is why they think that the ‘mugumo’ is worse than the ‘ithare’.

I.translation: A fair daughter’s father has no ears.
I.note: The father who wants to marry his daughter to the best among the young men who crowd his hut to woo her, turns a deaf ear on their foul words.
I.equivalent: Few men will be better than their interest bids them.

I.translation: A joke must not hit the belly.
I.note: The proverb means that there must be a limit also in joking.
I.equivalent: The jest is tolerable, but to do harm by jest is insufferable.

I.translation: For a jest one should not take the arrow out of the quiver.
From a jest comes a strife.
I.equivalent: Jests, like sweetmeats, have often sour sauce.

I.translation: A joke can break the earring.
I.equivalent: An ill-timed jest has ruined many.

I.translation: A trick is not an arrow.
I.equivalent: Good jests bite like lambs not like dogs.

I.translation: Two rich persons do not wish each other a bird of ill omen.
I.equivalent: Dog will not eat dog.

I.translation: Rich people cook their food in a potsherd.
I.equivalent: The tailor’s wife is worst clad.

I.translation: The village, which has got a whetstone, does not blunt the knife.
I.note: The sense of the proverb is that if in a village there is a good whetstone it does not mean that the villagers should purposely blunt their tools in order to whet them. The time will come when the whetstone will have to be used.
I.equivalent: Every thing is good in its season.

I.translation: A slaughterhouse is not without a little blood.
I.equivalent: Touch pitch, and you’ll be defiled.

K.proverb: Kaana ka ngari gakunyaga ta nyina
K.translation: The son of the leopard scratches like its mother.
K.equivalent: Like father like son.

K.translation: he baby nursed by its grandmother can never be corrected.
K.equivalent: Too much breaks the bag.

K.translation: One finger does not kill a louse.
K.equivalent: Union is strength.

K.proverb: Kagwaci ka mwana wene noko kahoragia mwaki
K.translation: It is always the potato of another family’s boy that extinguishes the fire.
K.note: The proverb alludes to the custom of roasting potatoes in the embers of a dying fire.
K.equivalent: Nobody calls himself rogue.

K.translation: The stream does not pass over an old stone (through respect to its age).
K.equivalent: Old age is honourable.

K.translation: The hunter’s son knows how to hunt.
K.equivalent: Like father, like son.

K.proverb: Kahii kogi ta ithe kabaritaga ta migwi
K.translation: A son as cunning as his father knows the arrows like father.
K.equivalent: Like carpenter like chips.

K.translation: A knife and a shaving-knife are alike.
K.note: The proverb means that if you do not have something you need, you will have something you can instead.
K.equivalent: Necessity is the mother of invention.

K.proverb: Kahiu karathime kariaga nyama cia kinandu
K.translation: The blessed knife (son) eats of the meat of the ‘kinandu’.
K.note: ‘Kinandu’ is a small calabash used to keep oil, fat and the best morsels of meat. They say that the father share the contents of the ‘kinandu’ with the most beloved son.

K.translation: He who is full does not understand what is told (about others’ troubles).
K.equivalent: Another’s burden does not worry us.

K.translation: The fed baby plays on its mother’s bed.
The rambling pole-cat leaves its house when there is banquet.
K.note: The son that leaves his father’s house for liberty’s sake will not share his father’s inheritance.

K.translation: A little idleness lost a tilled field.
K.equivalent: A little leak can sink a great ship.

K.translation: Kamau who is white becomes black.
K.note: 'Kamau' is typical name. The proverb means there is nothing constant in this world.

K.translation: A little idleness causes the ruin of the beehive.
K.note: The Kikuyu hang beehives on the branches of the forest trees, and it is their custom to visit them often to make sure that they are all right. For it might happen that if out of idleness one did not see them regularly, one would ultimately find the branch broken, the beehive fallen and the contents spoilt

K.translation: Many people together lift up the 'ndiri'.
K.note: 'Ndiri' is a heavy wooden mortar in which the Kikuyu women, when brewing beer, crush the sugar-cane.
K.equivalent: Many hands make light work.

K.translation: Take an oath only for the hand youslept on.
K.equivalent: Swear only to that which you know to be true.

K.translation: The whetstone in a village does no blunt the knife.
K.equivalent: Every potter praises his own pots.

K.proverb: Kanua karia kariire mbeu noko koragia 'ngahanda ki?'
K.translation: The mouth who ate the seeds asks, 'Now what shall I plant?'
K.equivalent: He sups ill who eats up all at dinner.

K.translation: Another’s mouth cannot take the oath for you.
K.equivalent: Every bird must hatch its own egg.

K.translation: The mouth is a chink.
K.equivalent: From the mouth come many futilities.

K.translation: The mouth sells the head.
K.equivalent: The tongue talks at the head's cost.

K.translation: You spoke (against yourself) with your own mouth.
K.note: Its means that one can sometimes condemn oneself in defending oneself.

K.translation: A small red snuff-box is a welcome.
K.note: The proverb refers to the Kikuyu custom of giving a pinch of snuff to their friends when they meet.

K.translation: The little bird that flaps its wings too much will spoil them
K.equivalent: One must crawl before one can walk.

K.translation: 'Kanywanjui' scratches its thigh.
K.note: ‘Kanywanjui’is a species of a tiny blue bird with a long bill, which sucks nectar from flowers. The proverb means that such birds, although very small, can do everything for their own needs, and do not require others’ help to have their legs scratched.
K.equivalent: Every man something can.

K.translation: He who is stricken knows how to defend himself.
K.equivalent: Scalded cats fear even cold water.

K.translation: It is not the owner, trampling his own field, that spoils it (but the others).
K.note: The proverb has arisen from the fact that many people if they have a bad harvest, say that it is the fault of other people who walked across their plantations.
K.equivalent: Nobody calls himself a rogue.

K.translation: A person will change his mind on something if left to sleep over it.
K.equivalent: Never leave till tomorrow what you can do today.

K.translation: Prophet copies a prophet.
K.equivalent: Like tree like fruit.

K.proverb: Karatu gatagwo na kuguru kwa mwene
K.translation: The shoe is made for the foot that will wear it.
K.equivalent: If the cap fits wear it.

K.translation: The baby that refuses its mother's breast, will never be full.
K.equivalent: Faint heart never won fair lady.

K.translation: The sleeping is turned by a stick: i.e. turns around to bite if disturbed or touched by a stick.
K.equivalent: Let the sleeping dogs lie.

K.translation: A stupid turtle-dove is sometimes surprised by night for wanting one more grain of castor-oil plant.
K.equivalent: Time stays not the fool's leisure.

K.translation: The mouth that has saliva does not lack words.
K.note: The proverb means that the man who has something to say will say it.

K.translation: The word that remains in the belly does not mean anything.
K.equivalent: Tell the truth and shame the devil.

K.translation: The song that has no leader, goes wrong.
K.equivalent: No longer pipe, no longer dance.

K.translation: The elders of the council do not jump over the brook.
K.note: Metaphorically the proverb means that the elders who are to judge a case must not hurry. But it often means that a person like a judge should not do anything undignified.

K.translation: The food eaten first lasts longest in the stomach.
K.equivalent: First impressions are most lasting.

K.translation: The dunghill grows by straws thrown upon it.
K.equivalent: Every little helps.

K.translation: A really good thing is ever good.
K.equivalent: A good tale is none the worse for being twice told.

K.proverb: Kiere kia njira-ini gitigwatagwo ni muura
K.translation: A grain of millet grown on the road will bear no ears.
K.note: The proverb means both that a promiscuous woman has little hope of bearing children, and that a thing in common use will not last long.
K.equivalent: A pot that belongs to many is ill stirred and worse boiled.

K.translation: The thigh is a bubble.
K.note: Thigh means full blooded youth. The proverb is for the young who scorn old people or make wrong use of their strength to sin. It reminds them that youth passes quickly.
K.equivalent: Young today, old tomorrow.

K.translation: What is white becomes black.
K.note: The proverb originates in the fact that the Africans are almost white when they are born, but become black by growing.
K.equivalent: There is nothing constant but change.

K.proverb: Kigina gitininukagio irio hande itari nguru
K.translation: The seeds kept are not finished before the ripening of the crops planted in the field.
K.equivalent: Every thing has its time, and that time must be watched.

K.translation: The argument breaks the strained cord of the bow.

K.equivalent: The argument relaxes the bent bow.

K.translation: The reason crosses even a flooding river.
The club is added to one's argument.
Having a good argument (in a discussion) is like having riches.
K.note: The five proverbs here above mean that he who can support his views or actions with a strong argument, will go through any difficulty and obtain what he wants.

K.translation: The fat of the 'kinandu' is not used to anoint a stranger.
K.note: ‘Kinandu’ is a small calabash used to keep oil, fat and the best morsels of meat.
K.equivalent: Charity begins at home.

K.translation: Who prospered with robbed things.
K.equivalent: Ill gotten goods seldom prosper.

K.proverb: Kindu kiuru no kironda, indi kiri rua rwa muhuhi
K.translation: A sore is a really bad thing; still it means luck to the doctor.
K.equivalent: It is an ill wind that blows nobody good.

K.proverb: Kindu kiuru no mundu ethukitie we mwene
K.translation: A really bad thing is to hurt oneself willfully.
K.equivalent: It is stupid to cut of your nose to spite your face.

K.translation: The thing you want must be begged from the owner.
K.note: This means that it must not be acquired from other people nor taken without permission
K.equivalent: It is not a sin to sell dear, but it is to make measure.

K.proverb: Kindong'o kiariire mai ni undu wa kwaga mayu ma gukira
K.translation: The beetle feeds on excrement for it can't fly high.
K.equivalent: If thou hast not a capon, feed on an onion.

K.translation: Any calabash that has got a bottom can stand upright.
K.note: he proverb means that God gives every man what is required by human nature: but it depends on man to exploit such gifts.
K.equivalent: Every man is the architect of his own fortune.

K.translation: The head is shaved at its owner's desire.
K.equivalent: Let every peddlar carry his own burden.

K.translation: An invalid does not go to two houses to ask for beer (since he cannot move).
K.equivalent: Old age is honourable.

K.translation: If a child has sinned all have sinned.
K.equivalent: One does the blame, another bears the shame.

K.translation: It is the gridiron that cries (for the slaughtered goat).
K.note: Everyone rejoices when a goat is killed, for each will have his piece of meat; only the gridiron on which the meat is roasted, weeps, i.e. crackles.

K.proverb: Kiriro kiri ituura gitingireka mundu akome
K.translation: One person weeping prevents all in a village from sleeping.
K.equivalent: One barking dog sets all the street a-barking.

K.translation: The forest in the heart cannot be cut down by somebody else.
K.note: Troubles in somebody's heart cannot be removed by somebody else.

K.translation: The fool makes other people stop on the road.
K.equivalent: The fool wastes the time of other people.

K.proverb: Kirimu kihithaga rwembea-ini rwa nyumba kiui gitikuonwo
K.translation: The fool hides himself under the eaves of the hut and thinks nobody will see him.
K.note: It refers to foolish people who invent silly excuses to conceal their faults.

K.proverb: Kirimu gia gwikigia kirugite kia muciarire
K.translation: He who feigns to be stupid is more stupid than the stupid-born.
K.equivalent: None is so deaf as those who won't hear.

K.translation: A fool can even suck the mother after she is dead.
A fool is like a beehive.
K.note: The proverb means that he is a fool who does not look after his own interest, like the beehive which allows itsself to be emptied.

K.proverb: Kiringiri gia aka ni rwenji rukirega
K.translation: To force a woman to do something she doesn't like is like forcing a blunt shaving knife to shave.
He who has a sore does not feel sick on account of it.
K.equivalent: We are blind to our own faults.

K.proverb: Kiruka gia kimbu gitithiragwo ni mung'ung'utu
K.translation: All the species of the chameleon family shall always have a protruding backbone.
K.equivalent: that that comes out of a cat will catch mice.

K.translation: Do not force a big thread into a bead with a small hole.
K.equivalent: Grasp all, lose all.

K.translation: A wasted thing cannot be eaten.
K.equivalent: Willful waste makes woeful want.

K.proverb: Kiura kiaringio ruui kiugaga nikio kieringia
K.translation: The frog that was helped across the river, said she had crossed by itself.
K.equivalent: Eaten bread is soon forgotten.

K.translation: Be patient, a desire is no pain.
K.note: This proverb is told to people who long after anything they cannot obtain.

K.translation: Desires tie.
K.note: If desire be endless, your cares will be so too.

K.translation: An empty bowl is not offered
K.note: It means that it is better to keep silence than to try to justify oneself by empty excuses.
K.equivalent: Be silent or speak something worth hearing.

K.translation: The dry firewood does not despise the wet one coming from the same tree.
K.equivalent: Dog will not bite dog.

K.translation: Mother's dry firewood laughed at the green one (and it did not think that both of them had but one common lot).
K.equivalent: Today me, tomorrow thee.

K.translation: Being praised leads to ruin. English equivalent: Praise without profit puts lit
K.equivalent: Praise without profit puts little in the pot.

K.translation: To tell the beads is not to cut the thread.
K.equivalent: Do not judge men or things at first sight.

K.proverb: Kuguru kuri muhu na kuri ime itihanaine
K.translation: A foot dirty of ashes is not a foot wet of dew (because the former holds firmly, while the latter skids).
The foot goes all the world over.
K.equivalent: It is perseverance that prevails.

K.translation: It is he who speaks that profits, not he who is spoken for.

K.proverb: Kugunirwo mwana no ta kugunirwo nyina
K.translation: To make the son happy is to make the mother happy.
Hurrying, is breaking.
K.equivalent: Haste makes waste.

K.translation: Erring is proper in a courageous person
K.equivalent: To err is human.

K.translation: To pass safely through danger (once) is no guarantee (for the next time).
K.equivalent: One can escape the rocks and perish in the sand.

K.translation: Males beg with the eyes.
K.note: It alludes to the Kikuyu custom according to which male guests, when invited to a beer party sit in the courtyard waiting for the host to pass round the drinks.

K.translation: To beg is not to steal.
Hunger and surfeit do not leave each other.
K.equivalent: Riches have wings.

K.translation: To pound the water in the mortar.
K.equivalent: To waste time and labour.

K.translation: To be black is not to be stupid.
K.equivalent: Little bodies may have great souls.

K.proverb: kuma ti kuma ta ihiga, na kuororoa ti kuororoa ta maai
K.translation: To be hard does not mean to be hard as stone, and to be soft does not mean to be soft as water.
K.equivalent: There is a measure in all things.

K.translation: To harvest is not so difficult as to keep the harvest.
K.equivalent: Keep some till more comes.

K.translation: Knowing too much is like being ignorant.
K.equivalent: Too much breaks the bag.

K.translation: He knows a place who lives in it.
K.equivalent: Every man knows his own business best.

K.translation: Long live my mother and her ugliness.
To become small is not the same as being cut.
To be caught is not to be imrisoned.
K.equivalent: There is many a slip, 'twixt the cup and the lip.

K.translation: Some are males (useful people) and some can only fill the gourds (useless people).
K.equivalent: Some good, some bad, as sheep come to the fold.

K.proverb: Kuri guciara uru ta kihia gigiciara na mutwe
K.translation: There are women who give forth a bad issue, just like the sorghum that bears its fruit on the head (instead of growing it underground like most Kikuyu crops).
One cannot put the 'ndebe' into a broken ear-lobe.
K.note: The proverb means that these are things once broken cannot be soldered.

K.translation: There are people who, like sugar cane, are killed for being sweet.
K.equivalent: He who makes himself a sheep shall be eaten by the wolf.

K.translation: There are lucky and unlucky people.
K.equivalent: The wind of luck is inconstant.

K.proverb: Kuri ukuu utatumwo, ta wa nyungu
K.translation: There are things, like the earthen pot, which if ever broken can't be repaired.
K.equivalent: For some evils there is no remedy.

K.translation: To eat first is not to be a glutton.
To eat much means to spoil one's belly.
K.equivalent: Too much breaks the bag.

K.proverb: Kuria nai gutigiragia mundu akaria wega
K.translation: To eat bad food (today) does not prevent a person from having good food (tomorrow).
K.equivalent: Change of fortune is the lot of life.

K.translation: One does not eat the soil, but the fruit thereon.
The way of eating a debt is paying it.
K.equivalent: He that gets out of debt grows rich.

K.proverb: Kuriithia imwe ti kwenda kwa mwene
K.translation: To graze only one goat is not the owner's will.
K.equivalent: Evils come though we do not want them.

K.translation: o have come to an agreement does not mean that the agreement may not be broken.
K.equivalent: The cat and the dog may kiss, yet are none the better friends.

K.translation: To till the land is to love oneself.
K.equivalent: Work is well done that is well loved.

K.translation: It is bad to be a fool.

K.proverb: Kuruga ti kwega, amu kiura kioragire uthoni na iruga
K.translation: To leap is bad, since the male-frog by leaping broke up the betrothal.
K.note: The proverb originates in the following fable. One day the male-frog went to his fiancée's home to arrange the marriage with her father. But as soon as the fiancée noticed the indecorous leaping-posture assumed by the male frog during the conversation, she refused to marry him. The Kikuyu tell the proverb to express their esteem for decency and modesty.
K.equivalent: Loquacity storms the ear, but modesty takes the heart.

K.proverb: Kurua, kugurana na kuriha thiri gutiiriragwo
K.translation: Nobody feels sorry for having been circumcissed, for having bought his wife and for having paid hi debts.
K.note: The proverb means that there are certain things that leave no regrets.

K.translation: Being circumcissed is like being scalded.
K.note: This means that the pain of the circumcission is a few minutes' pain.

K.translation: Being circumcissed is like building the 'itara'.
K.note: The 'itara' is a trellis of twigs suspended a short distance above the fire-place in the Kikuyu hut to prevent sparks from setting fire to the thatched roof. The same word is often used to mean the whole hut. Thus this proverb means that a young man as soon as circumcissed, must realise that the years of irresponsibility are over and that he must see about building his hut and starting a new home.
K.equivalent: A married man must turn his staff into a stake.

K.translation: A blow does not always injure.

K.proverb: Kuma kwa mbaa guthii kwa heho
K.translation: To come from rime and go into the bitter cold.
K.equivalent: To fall out of the frying pan into the fire.

K.translation: To come out of one's house means learning.
K.equivalent: Travel makes a wise man better.

K.proverb: Kwa mucuni ni gwateirwo ni muhituki
K.translation: Mucuni's place was ruined by the traveller.
K.note: 'Mucuni' is the name of a person who refused hospitality to a passer by. Since hospitality is traditionally sacred among the Kikuyu, they say that this traveller cursed Mucuni's house which went to ruin.

K.proverb: Kwa munegeni gukiura, kwa mukiri kworire tene
K.translation: The house of the talkative man perished long after that of the quiet.
K.note: It is easy for somebody who is friendly to get help from others.

K.translation: On the way to one's beloved there are no hills.
Talking is loving one another.
K.equivalent: Friendship increases by visiting friends.
To talk is not to grumble

K.translation: To talk is not to decide.
To start a family is to start troubles
K.equivalent: When a man is married his troubles begin.

K.translation: To prepare is not to be afraid.
K.equivalent: Let him that wants peace prepare for war.

K.translation: To see for one's self is different from being told.
K.equivalent: Words are but wind, but seeing is believing.

K.translation: To see the crop in the fields is not to eat it.
K.equivalent: There is many a slip, 'twixt the cup and the lip.

M.translation: Spilt water has nobody to collect it.
M.equivalent: It is no use crying over spilt milk.

M.translation: Lukewarm water is not hot water.
Many births mean many burials.
M.note: The proverb means that in the family tree where there are many children one must expect many griefs too; and that people who run many businesses must also expect many reverses.
M.equivalent: Much coin much care.

M.translation: Trials mean successes.
M.equivalent: Where there is a will there is a way.

M.translation: Old fat sings no song.
M.note: This means that he who goes to dance does not anoint himself with rancid fat. The word 'fat' is used for 'beauty, youth'. The proverb means that old folks cannot have admirers as young ones; that old people cannot hope to have more children.
M.equivalent: Water run by, will not turn a mill.

M.translation: The smearing begins on one's face.
M.note: Actually the Kikuyu who smear themselves very often, always begin the anointing on the face, and laugh at people who begin on any other part of the body.
M.equivalent: There is a time and a way for all things.

M.translation: Lies are dangerous.
M.equivalent: Liars have short wings.

M.translation: Lies are no debt.

M.proverb: Maitho ma andu matiendaga kindu kihinju
M.translation: Men's eyes do not like to see anything thin.
M.note: The proverb refers to children, oxen and goats.

M.proverb: Maitho ma arume ti ma irang'a
M.translation: Men's eyes are not the eyes of the 'irang'a'.
M.note: 'Irang'a' is an insect with very tiny eyes. The proverb means that the eyes of this insect see very little, while men's eyes see everything.

M.translation: Men's eyes are not like the 'mambo'.
M.note: 'Mambo' are the holes the Kikuyu make in the hides for fastening them to the ground when they dry them in the sun.

M.proverb: Maitho ma ciura matigiragia ng'ombe inyue
M.translation: The eyes of frogs do not prevent cattle from drinking.
M.equivalent: Do what thou ought, let come what may.

M.translation: The eyes which see each other are destined to see each other again.
M.equivalent: Friendship increases by visiting friends.

M.translation: Tears are no language.
M.equivalent: Tears, idle tears.

M.proverb: Marakara ma arume matituuraga ta ma aka
M.translation: Men's anger does not last so long as women's.
M.equivalent: Women are as prone to revenge injuries as men to forgive them.

M.translation: Getting into rage means being proud.
Run-by water does not quench the thirst.
M.equivalent: Water run by, will not turn a mill.

M.translation: The water that is not yours flows away while you are folding the 'ituma'.
M.note: 'Ituma' is the leaf of a kind of edible arum. Out of these large leaves the Kikuyu used to drink water.

M.proverb: Mathanwa mari kiondo kimwe matiagaga gukomorania
M.translation: Many axes in one basket must hit against each other.
Some people do not like the building of a hut, though they like the 'Murugurio'.
M.note: 'Murugurio' is a kind of dedication-ceremony held by the witch-doctor to solemnize the completion of a new hut. On such occassion the owner of the hut distributes beer to his relations and to the people who assisted him in the building.
M.equivalent: There is scarcity of friendship but not of friends.

M.translation: They who leave one another forget one another.
M.equivalent: Out of sight, out of mind.

M.translation: Slips outnumber falls.
M.equivalent: Every slip is not a fall.

M.translation: Days pass quickly.
M.equivalent: Time fleeth away without delay.

M.translation: The days are a hurry, i.e. go quickly.
M.equivalent: Time fleeth away without delay.

M.translation: Not all days are sundays.
M.equivalent: Christmas comes but once in a year.

M.translation: The eggs of males do not hatch each other.
M.note: The proverb means both that any man prefers living with a woman rather than another man, and that there ought not to be two people commanding in one home.
M.equivalent: Two sparrows upon one ear of wheat cannot agree.

M.translation: The important things are left in the locker.
M.note: In other words, they are not told to everybody.
M.equivalent: Tell not all you know.

M.translation: My stolen or damaged lamb must be replaced by another.
M.equivalent: An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth

M.translation: War is not porridge.
Women's strife has no sheep
M.note: According to the Kikuyu custom the one that wounds another in a quarrel must pay a sheep as a fine. The proverb means that in women's strifes nobody incurs such a fine, for their quarrels are usually words only.
M.equivalent: Words are for women, actions for men.

M.proverb: Mbari ya ngeka makorirwo matari meka
M.translation: They who said 'I shall do' became people who had done nothing.
M.equivalent: Never leave that till tomorrow which you can today.

M.translation: The mouse finishes the hide by gnawing.
M.equivalent: Little strokes fell great oaks.

M.translation: The future is not so much regretted as the past.

M.proverb: Mbere ni gikeno thutha ni maithori
M.translation: Tears follow joy.

M.proverb: Mbere no mbere thutha no mugiano
M.translation: Before is before: afterwards there is nothing but repining.
M.equivalent: Resist the beginnings.

M.translation: Many buffaloes are no meat.
M.equivalent: If you run after two hares, you will catch neither.

M.translation: A small flower has no smell.
M.equivalent: A little barrel can give but little meal.

M.translation: The goat is attracted by salt.
M.equivalent: The bait not the hook catches the fish.

M.translation: No alarm is shouted for a goat (because it is not a dangerous beast).
M.equivalent: Do not waste time and money on unworthy things.

M.translation: The goat and the child are not insulted (because they cannot defend themselves).
One can always find the goat to pay the penalty for having defecated in another's house.
M.note: According to Kikuyu customs he who defecates in another's house is liable to be fined a goat. The proverb means that he whoincurred such penalty will contrive to find the means to pay it.
M.equivalent: Necessity sharpens industry.

M.translation: A chattering goat does not keep its tongue.
M.note: The word 'goat' is here used instead of 'people'.
M.equivalent: A fool may ask more questions in an hour than a wise man can answer in seven years.

M.translation: Mburi yene muitha ni gutu
M.note: The proverb means that a stranger coming in when a slaughtered goat is distributed, must not expect to be given a choice morsel, but rather an inferior part like an ear. Metaphorically the proverb means that a prudent person keeps for himself and his family the best parts of anything instead of giving them away to his visitors and friends.

M.translation: The goat which eats ashes does not hide its habit.
M.note: The Kikuyu live under the same roof as their animals. So if any goat forms the habit of leaving its place and coming to lick ashes at the fire, it will soon be discovered. In the same manner the vices of the wicked will soon be known.

M.translation: An old goat does not sneeze without cause.
M.note: The proverb means that old folks speak the truth and do not speak without reason.
M.equivalent: Old dogs bark not for nothing.

M.translation: Goats are not bananas (which are given for nothing).
M.equivalent: There are no pains without pains.

M.proverb: Mburi ya ngia yaringirira no uguo bata uringagirira
M.translation: When the poor man's goat is about to kid, then the need drops also.
M.note: The proverb means that if a man rejoices because his goat is going to kid and so increase property, a sudden need might   to sell his goat.
M.equivalent: Count not your chickens before they be hatched.

M.proverb: Mbu ya arume itikagio ni athamaki
M.translation: Men's alarm-shouts are answered by the elders.
M.note: The proverb means that if the alarm is shouted only by women one can make light of it; but if the alarm is cried by men there exists a real danger. Metaphorically the proverb means that women cannot claim any right of discussing or giving evidence in court.
M.equivalent: Let women spin and not preach.

M.translation: The bell needs its tongue.
M.note: In this proverb the word 'bell' means 'woman', and 'tongue' means 'man'.
M.equivalent: Wives must be bad, be they good or bad.

M.proverb: Mburungo nyinyi iri muthiomeri irugite nene itari muthiomeri
M.translation: A trifle well presented becomes more precious than a thing of great value badly presented.
M.equivalent: It is not the value of a gift that matters but the intentions of the giver.

M.translation: A distant water does not quench one's thirst.
Be not too proud lest you ruin yourself.
The 'miano' cannot be confused, but the mouth can.
M.note: 'Miano' are the small gourds used by witch-doctors to contain the divining stones. The proverbs means that the divining stones cannot fail to tell the truth, though it may happen that the witch-doctor does not tell it.
M.equivalent: God cures and the doctor takes the fee.

M.translation: The words are the odour of the heart.
M.equivalent: The tongue ever turns to the aching tooth.

M.translation: Two hides are not laid out at the same time.
M.equivalent: One cannot be in two places at once.

M.proverb: Miguire ya ngu na ya migogo ti imwe
M.translation: he fall of branches and that of big trees are not the same.
Speaking in a whisper is followed by hiding (in order to steal).
M.note: The proverb means that people who whisper are probably arranging something evil.
M.equivalent: Beware of a silent dog and still water.

M.proverb: Mitheko itari githimi yumaga kanua-ini ka irimu
M.translation: Laugh without measure comes out of fools' mouths.
M.equivalent: The laughter of fools.

M.translation: One's pocket is not a repository (in which all people can put their hands).
M.note: Pocket means in this case home affairs.
M.equivalent: Scald not your lips in another man's pottage.

M.translation: The hand has not to be put into another's pocket.
M.equivalent: Scald not your lips in another man's pottage.

M.translation: He who is in necessity does not feel ashamed (to ask for help).
A cob of maize can knock down a giant.
M.equivalent: A small leak will sink a great ship.

M.translation: It is he who travels that finds the tusk.
M.equivalent: God helps those who help themselves.

M.translation: Yaws is caught through friendship.
M.note: The proverb means that just as the disease is contracted by contact with infected people, so bad habits are acquired by consorting with bad people.
M.equivalent: Who keeps company with a wolf will learn how to howl.

M.translation: He who looks for another must find him.
M.equivalent: He who will seek may find.

M.translation: He who walks with a mangy man becomes mangy.
M.equivalent: He who keeps company with a wolf will learn to howl.

M.translation: Parents are merciful.

M.proverb: Muciari ndairagio ngoro ni kimira kia mwana wake
M.translation: Parents do not feel sick when wiping the mucus from their child's nose.
Parents do not take away the earth that covers the root of the sugar cane.
M.note: As a good farmer does not uncover the roots of the sugar cane lest it may dry, so good parents have a limit also in punishing their children.

M.translation: Parents are proud of their chidren.
The house is not ruled by him that did not build it.
M.equivalent: Mind your own business.

M.translation: The house is for sleeping in by night, not for staying in by day.
M.equivalent: There is a time for all things.

M.translation: The house which has goats does not lack miscarriages.
M.equivalent: Who has land, has war.

M.translation: The strong smell (of roasting meat) causes the hyena to break its leg.
M.equivalent: Hasty climbers have sudden falls.

M.translation: He who advises a fool does not lay down his 'muthigi'.
M.note: 'Muthigi' is the staff of the elders.

M.translation: One man alone in a tribunal can say nothing, i.e. can take no decision.
A slanderer has no peaceful home.
M.equivalent: Slander flings stones at itself.

M.proverb: Mugambo uri kugua thi nduoyagwo; woyagwo na ungi
M.translation: A word that has fallen to the ground cannot be picked up: it is picked up by another.
M.equivalent: Time and words can never be recalled.

M.translation: A word given must not be retaken.
He who broils two maize cobs (at the same time) burns one of them.
M.equivalent: He who hunts two hares leaves one and loses the other.

M.translation: A broken necklace cannot be made whole again.
M.equivalent: A broken friendship may be soldered, but will never be sound.

M.proverb: Mugathi wa kuona uteaga wa mwene
M.translation: The necklace found makes you lose your own, too.
M.equivalent: Ill-gotten things seldom prosper.

M.translation: The foreigner evacuates in the cemetery (for he does not know the place and its customs).
One does not give any beer to a foolish visitor.
M.note: he proverb means both that it is not honourable for the host to give hospitality to a fool, and that it is silly to give beer to a fool since he does not enjoy it
M.equivalent: He is not the fool that the fool is, but he that with the fools deals.

M.translation: A guest does not eat as much as he wants; i.e. he must not be greedy.
The guest is like a river, i.e. he passes quickly.
M.equivalent: Fish and guests smell at three days old.

M.translation: He who harvests by night, reaps chaff.
M.equivalent: There is a time for all things.

M.translation: He who has been advised is wise.
M.equivalent: A man forewarned is forearmed.

M.proverb: Mugiri rwa kunyitura agirire rwa kunyitia
M.translation: One can cause the illness which he wanted to cure.
M.equivalent: The cure may be worse than the disease.

M.translation: He who irritates will be scratched.
M.equivalent: Let the sleeping dogs lie.

M.translation: One trunk does not close a river.
M.equivalent: One flower makes no garland.

M.translation: he she-sheep can break the cooking pot, and still she has no horn.
M.note: Cooking pot means here an affair of great importance. The meaning of the proverb is that a fool can spoil wise people's affairs.

M.translation: A field begins to become wilderness from a side; i.e. from a small place.
M.equivalent: A little neglect may breed a great mischief.

M.proverb: Mugunda wa mwere umenyagwo na ngetho
M.translation: One knows a field of millet from its crop.
M.equivalent: A tree is known by its fruits.

M.translation: Another's field is not praised.
M.note: he proverb refers to the fact that the Kikuyu when they are drunk imagine themselves very rich, and so become proud of others' riches.

M.translation: The man who buys something at a place near by is like the man who is given something.
M.equivalent: That is little esteemed that costs little.

M.proverb: Mugui utari wa awa ni ukundemburira thiaka
M.translation: The arrow which is not my father's, pierces my quiver.
M.equivalent: Ill gotten goods seldom prosper.

M.translation: He who pays another with his own things, does not bleed.
M.note: The proverb means that one spends his money willingly when he needs help.

M.translation: He who stands close to his things does not lose them.
M.equivalent: The master's eyes make the horse fat.

M.translation: The messenger of peace has no two knives (presents).
M.equivalent: Messengers should neither be beheaded nor hanged.

M.translation: He who plants is not he who eats.
M.equivalent: Man proposes, God disposes.

M.translation: The one with diarrhoea must look for a bush.
M.equivalent: Let him that is cold blow coal.

M.translation: He who is spoken to at both ears does not understand.
M.equivalent: Too much consulting confounds.

M.translation: A liar does not laugh (for if a liar laughs when he tells a lie he is not believed).

M.proverb: Muhenia ago oigaga murimu uri guthira
M.translation: He who would deceive the witch-doctors says that his illness is finished
M.equivalent: Hide nothing from thy minister, physician and lawyer.

M.translation: The deceived has many more days than the deceiver.
M.equivalent: Liars have short wings.

M.translation: The deceived is not so cunning as the deceiver.
He who receives must not measure.
M.equivalent: Do not look a gift horse in the mouth.

M.proverb: Muhikana na kuria ahikanaga na guitwo
M.translation: He who takes his food in a hurry, is also choked in a hurry.
M.equivalent: Haste makes waste.

M.translation: He who hastens eats money; i.e. wastes his money.
M.equivalent: Haste makes waste.

M.translation: He who is in a hurry sews a garment (whereas he could mend the old one).
M.equivalent: Haste makes waste.

M.translation: A clan is not a wall (which can be destroyed).
M.note: The Kikuyu are very keen on keeping distinction between one clan and the other. That is why they say that distinction cannot be cancelled.

M.translation: He who is quiet has no troubles
He that has been beaten in a quarrel does not sleep in the court-yard.
M.equivalent: Scalded cats fear even cold water.

M.translation: He who is surfeited calls the hungry one glutton.
M.equivalent: It is easy preaching to the fasting in a full belly.

M.translation: The thief makes the poisoner change his residence.
M.note: The proverb comes from the following story. A witch-doctor intended to poison a thief. But the thief always managed to steal the poison and the witch-doctor had to find a fresh home.

M.proverb: Muici na kihii atigaga kieha kiarua
M.translation: He who robbed in company with a boy will live in fear until the boy is circumcissed.
M.equivalent: What children hear at home soon flies abroad.

M.proverb: Muici na mundu muka atigaga kieha akua
M.translation: He who robbed in company with a woman, will live in fear until she dies (for a woman cannot keep a secret).
M.equivalent: Woman conceals only what she knows not.

M.translation: The thief cannot keep fit, because his stools contain undigested food.
M.note: The proverb means that a thief, who eats his food in a hurry and with the fear of being caught, cannot enjoy good health.
M.equivalent: Ill-gotten things seldom prosper.

M.proverb: Muici uri hunyu arindagira uri maguta
M.translation: An ugly thief is more likely to be caught than one smeared with fat: i.e. carefully dressed.
M.note: The proverb means that a robber who cannot dissemble will soon be discovered, while the thief who can sham, will continue to flourish.

M.proverb: Muici utari munyite ni muria gake
M.translation: The thief who has not been caught eats of his own.
M.note: he proverb means that stolen goods belong to the thief if he is not caught.

M.proverb: Muici wa muthenya ni oio, na wa utuku ni oio
M.translation: He who robs in the day is known, and he who robs in the night is known, too.
M.equivalent: What is done by night appears by day.

M.translation: The big thorn laughs at the small one.
M.equivalent: The greatest thieves punish the small ones.

M.translation: A cousin does not ask and is not refused anything (because he is a member of the kindred).
A cousin is not denied a meal.
M.note: A cousin does not ask and is not refused anything (because he is a member of the kindred).
M.equivalent: Charity begins at home.

M.translation: He who stays near a corpse cannot help weeping.
To stay together is to kno each other.

M.proverb: Muikari muti gitina niwe ui kiria thambo iriaga
M.translation: He who stays at the foot of the tree knows what 'thambo' eat.
M.note: 'Thambo' are the black ants which live and nest on the trees. The proverb means that nobody knows the affairs of a home, society, etc. better than he who lives or has part in it.
M.equivalent: Every man knows his own business best.

M.proverb: Muikari na hunyu ndakoragwo onete maguta akarega kwihaka
M.translation: He who is ugly, is not so because he refused to smear himself with fat (but rather because he had no fat to smear himself with).
M.equivalent: We are but what God made us.

M.translation: He that shoots an arrow does not know whom he will hit.
M.equivalent: You know not where a stone may light.

M.translation: He on whom fortune has frowned cannot live long.
The man overwhelmed by another's arguments does not return to discuss matters.
M.equivalent: Once bitten, twice shy.

M.translation: He who keeps good hours is not surprised by night.
M.equivalent: Early to bed, early to rise, make a man healthy, wealthy and wise.

M.translation: A woman that hangs about does not lack children.
M.note: The proverb refers to the married women who, failing to have children of their husbands', go around looking for other men.

M.translation: One returns to the old wife when the young one dies.
M.equivalent: Half a loaf is better than no bread.

M.proverb: Muka uri kironda ainagira gitiro ihugo
M.translation: The woman who has a sore dances on the outskirts.
M.equivalent: A guilty conscience needs no accuser.

M.translation: The woman who has children does not desert her home.

M.proverb: Muka wa mwathi ahingaga na kuguru etereire kigurumuki oke
M.translation: The hunter's wife, awaiting her husband's return, closes the door only with her foot; i.e. she leaves the door unbolted so that her husband may enter more quickly with his prey.

M.proverb: Muikarire ni umwe no murarire ti umwe
M.translation: To stay together is not the same as to have the same type of life.
M.note: People often agree in words but not in judgement.

M.translation: You will pass through the ear-holes.
M.note: The Kikuyu pierce the lobes and the upper part of their ears to put wooden sticks in the holes as an ornament. They use this proverb referring to people attempting to perform impossibilities.
M.equivalent: It is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of heaven.

M.translation: He that milks is not he that holds the calf.
M.equivalent: Every man to his own job.

M.translation: The miser denies food to him who is surfeited.
M.note: The proverb refers to stingy people who deny some help  to others who would in turn be the most helpful.

M.translation: He who gets up early returns early.
M.equivalent: The early bird catches the worm.

M.translation: He who ages in the 'githunu' is not known by other people how old he is.
M.note: 'Githunu' is a dormitory where unmarried people sleep. The proverb means that he who has no hut and no wife will age without having children to tell him how old he is.

M.translation: Old man, divide, and teach me how to divide.
M.note: his proverb shows how the Kikuyu respected old people, to whom was left the distribution of meat, beer, etc. at all gatherings.
M.equivalent: Old age is honourable.

M.translation: The woman whose sons have died is richer than a barren woman.
The pot-maker cooks in a potsherd.
M.equivalent: The tailor's wife is worst clad.

M.proverb: Mumeni mundu ungi amwitaga kiongo kia njau
M.translation: He who despises another man, calls him 'head of calf'.
M.note: Owing to their esteem for oxen, it is not dishonourable for the Kikuyu to be told he has a head as big as that of an ox. But it is shameful to be called 'head of calf' since the calf is a useless animal.

M.translation: He who despises another steals even the snuff from his nose; i.e. has no respect for him.
Man counts what he is refused, not what he is given.
M.equivalent: We are more mindful of injuries than benefits.

M.proverb: Mundu mugi ndari muhere wa uhoro
M.translation: A wise man does not need to be told a thing twice.
M.equivalent: A word is enough to the wise.

M.translation: The witch-doctor cannot do for himself what he does for others.

M.proverb: Mundu mugo wa gwithokia ndari rua
M.translation: The witch-doctor who goes to see a patient without being sent for, will not have the hide of the slaughtered goat; i.e. will have no reward.
M.equivalent: Give no counsel no salt till you are asked for it.

M.translation: The witch-doctor of the place is not needed.
M.equivalent: Never a prophet was valued in his own country.

M.translation: Woman and sky cannot be understood.
M.equivalent: Woman, wind and fortune are ever changing.

M.translation: A woman must not be killed.
M.note: The reasons for this proverb are the facts that the woman is too weak to defend herself and that only the woman can produce children.

M.translation: A woman is not sent to collect debts.
M.equivalent: Let women spin and not preach.

M.translation: The obedient man gets through.
M.equivalent: Do what thou ought and dread no shame.

M.translation: Men act promptly.

M.proverb: Mundu urakanyuira niwe ui kari rita
M.translation: He that has drunk once, knows that to drink is a pleasure; i.e. he who has experienced something knows whether it is good or bad.
M.equivalent: Experience is the father of wisdom.

M.proverb: Mundu uri na undu otaga mwaki na riua
M.translation: The man who warms himself at the fire while the sun is shining, does so for some reason.
People who have no goat do not desire meat.
M.note: 'Sour grapes,' as the fox said when he could not reach them.

M.proverb: Mundu utathiaga athinjaga mwati atoi ndurume iri gicegu
M.translation: He that does not travel slaughters the she goat as he is ignorant of a ram in his fold; i.e. he is stupid.

M.proverb: Mundu utathiaga oi no nyina urugaga
M.translation: He who does not travel only knows his mother's cooking.
