M.proverb: Mundu wa rurugi ourugagwo akerwo niwe wourugana
M.translation: He who is wont to provoke others, is called a provoker even when he is provoked.
M.equivalent: A liar is not believed when he speaks the truth.

M.translation: He who has circumcised me once does not return to do it again.
M.note: The proverb means that he who has erred or has been cheated once, becomes wise and will not be cheated a second time.
M.equivalent: He who stumbles twice over one stone deserves to break his shins.

M.translation: One mouth must be changed; i.e. it is not good to talk always with the same person nor about the same things.
M.equivalent: Change of pasture makes fat calves.

M.translation: Fortune passes.
M.equivalent: When fortune smiles, take the advantage.

M.translation: Fortune is beyond the bush; i.e. the obstacle.
M.equivalent: He that endures overcomes.

M.translation: Fortune is not a thing that must surely come.
M.equivalent: Fortune is not of every day.

M.translation: He who is thirsty goes to the river.
M.equivalent: Let him that is cold blow the coal.

M.proverb: Mura na mundu ti mura na hiti
M.translation: To be robbed by a person is different from being robbed by a hyena.
M.note: The proverb means that if you were robbed by a person, you can hope to be recompensed for the damage; but if a member of your family or a head of your herd has been stoled by a hyena, there is no hope for redress.
M.equivalent: There are injuries beyond redress.

M.translation: It is not the killer that moans, but the killed.
He who refuses (to do something) when asked, does not refuse when forced.
He who refuses to obey cannot command.
M.equivalent: He that knows not how to obey, knows not how to command.

M.proverb: Muremwo ni ndugo oigaga nja iri mahiga
M.translation: He who cannot dance says that the yard is stony.
M.equivalent: A bad workman complains of his tools.

M.proverb: Muri kuria ta athi a thatu
M.translation: Sometimes one eats bad food like the hunters when they are out hunting in the misty season.
M.note: This proverb comes from the fact that hunters, who stay in the forest or in the plain for rather a long time must often be content with cold raw food.
M.equivalent: When bread is wanting, oaten cakes are excellent.

M.proverb: Muria na gati ndoi muria na kaara ni akuhia
M.translation: He who eats with a stick does not know that he who eats with the fingers gets scalded.
He who eats cooked food has someone who cooks for him.
M.note: The proverb means that he who desires a thing sufficiently either can easily have it, or will make efforts to get it.
M.equivalent: Nothing is imposssible to a willing mind.

M.translation: He is not condemned who eats even unripe maize of his own fields
M.equivalent: Every man is a king in his own house.

M.translation: He who eats alone dies alone.

M.proverb: Murimirwo ni ithe ndoi indo iri bata
M.translation: He who has fields tilled by his father, does not know that things are precious.
M.equivalent: What costs little is little esteemed.

M.translation: One must not break the arm of him who tills the fields.
M.equivalent: Do not kill the goose that lays the golden eggs.

M.translation: One tiller does not fill the granary.
M.equivalent: Union is strength.

M.translation: He that tills the earth is not he that eats(its fruits).
Sweetness does not satisfy hunger.
M.note: The proverb means that pleasures do not quench the thirst for many more pleasures.
M.equivalent: Sweet words butter no parsnips

M.translation: Pleasure cannot be communicated.
M.note: This proverb means that he who has any reason for   rejoicing, cannot feel unhappy even if his friends or neighbours are grieved.

M.translation: Pleasures do not last so much as gratitude.
M.note: The proverb means that few virtues are as great as gratitude and that few joys are greater than that of being thanked for a service.
M.equivalent: Gratitude surpasses all other virtues.

M.translation: Sweetness eats up itself
Sweetness brings sorrow.
M.equivalent: Pleasure stings even though it pleases.

M.translation: Sweetness spoils teeth.
Sweetness makes the vulture descend from the tree.
M.equivalent: Beauty draws more than oxen.

M.proverb: Murio wa njohi ni uriukagwo, no wa indo nduriukagwo
M.translation: The drunkenness of beer passes away, but the drunkenness of wealth lasts forever.
M.equivalent: Avarice increases with wealth.

M.translation: He who asks too much will not eat anything.
M.equivalent: All covet, all lose.

M.translation: They who live together must be merciful.
M.equivalent: Bear and forbear is good philosophy.

M.proverb: Murimu nduri hinya ugitonya mwiri ta ukiuma
M.translation: Illness enters the body with less difficulty than it meets on going away.
M.equivalent: Misfortunes come on wing and depart on foot.

M.proverb: Murimu wa mucoka niguo uragaga mundu
M.translation: Illness enters the body with less difficulty than it meets on going away.
M.equivalent: Misfortunes come on wing and depart on foot.

M.proverb: Murimu wa mucoka niguo uragaga mundu
M.translation: It is the illness that returns that kills people.
M.equivalent: Resist the beginnings.

M.translation: The poisoner cannot stop the effect of the poison.
M.note: The proverb refers to the superstition by which a person who has been poisoned cannot go to his poisoner to have the effect of poison neutralized by his arts but must go to another person, who is called 'murogori'.

M.translation: He who looks at another's field sees many more weeds than does its owner.
M.equivalent: To be blind to one's own faults.

M.translation: He who cooks food for men, does not lack big veins, i.e. bruises.
M.note: This proverb means that he who works for a master must do his duty to avoid punishment.
M.equivalent: Men like facts not words.

M.proverb: Murunguru wa njamba utahaga na ime
M.translation: He who rises early skips in the dew.
M.note: The proverb means that people who get up early finish their work early.
M.equivalent: The early bird catches the worm.

M.translation: The 'mururi' does not build.
M.note: Mururi' is a forest tree with beautiful red flowers, but yielding very poor timber.
M.equivalent: All is not gold that glitters.

M.translation: He who circumcises the boy was a boy, too.
He who circumcises the male was circumcised.
M.equivalent: The child is father of the man.

M.proverb: Mutego ti ngoro, ni wathi warera
M.translation: It is not the trap that counts, but the art of trapping.
M.equivalent: A good archer is known by his aim, not his arrows.

M.translation: Both he that chases and he that is chased become tired.
M.equivalent: Everyone has his own troubles.

M.proverb: Muthakwa wa athi nduthiragwo ni gicanjara
M.translation: The 'muthakwa-tree' will not discontinue to produce branches of only one shape.
M.equivalent: Like father like son.

M.translation: The wise man who is not taught is not a wise man.

M.proverb: Muthinio ni kuona aruga muthinio ni wagi
M.translation: He who is troubled by having (property) is better off than he who is troubled by poverty.
He who sends somebody to a witch-doctor on his behalf must believe all he is told.
He who is sought by a man already in the courtyard, has no way of escape.
M.note: To understand this proverb one must bear in mind that the Kikuyu hut has only one entrance and no window.
M.equivalent: There is no medicine against death.

M.translation: He who travels alone, dies alone.
He who starts (on a long journey) does not put a banana to toast under the ashes (for he is not sure he will come back to eat it).
He who travels sees many things.
M.note: The world is a great book, of which they who never stir from home read only one page.

M.translation: He who starts early returns early.
He who buries (the others) is not buried.
M.equivalent: Do good, but do not expect to receive it.

M.translation: He who turns others around may also turn himself around.
M.equivalent: According to the Kikuyu superstition to turn a person round is to wish him misfortune.

M.translation: He who has a bone (to lick) is happier than he who gathers up his limbs for hunger.
M.equivalent: When bread is wanting, oaten cakes are excellent.

M.translation: The European has (among the natives) no trustworthy man.
The European has (among the natives) no trustworthy man.
Wickedness begets remorse.
He that dislikes a person--is he God?
M.note: The proverb means that if anyone is hated by men, he is not necessarily hated also by God.
M.equivalent: God is just.

M.translation: He that is lame of heart--unlike him that is lame of foot--cannot be recognized.
M.equivalent: All is not gold that glitters.

M.proverb: Muthuri utari kahii niwe wiriragira ngururu
M.translation: The married man who has no son goes himself to scare away the birds from his harvest.
A dried up tree does not bear a green one.
M.equivalent: One cannot get blood out of a stone.

M.translation: The tree falls on the man who stands by it.
A tree that is not intended to be felled, is not aimed at with an axe.
M.note: It is told to people who, devoting themselves to many things at the same time, finish none.
M.equivalent: Jack of all trades and master of none.

M.translation: He who leaves a bunch of bananas finds a whole stalk.
M.equivalent: Give and spend, and God will send.

M.translation: The man left where there was once a hut, will certainly find something.

M.proverb: He who leaves a white goat will meet another of the same colour.
M.equivalent: Contentment is above wealth.

M.translation: Danger makes a man rise from bed.
M.equivalent: Men in danger need no spur.

M.translation: Misfortunes frustrates one's plans.
M.equivalent: Man proposes, God disposes.

M.proverb: Mutirima wa kirimu witirimagia na mugi
M.translation: A fool's walking-stick helps the wise man to stand
M.note: This proverb means that wise people know how to get profit from things that a man thinks useless.
M.equivalent: A wise man gets learning from those who have none themselves.

M.translation: He who lives a long time (in one place) must find what he wants.

M.proverb: Mutumia angikura atari mwana ndangiona mutahiri maai
M.translation: The woman that gets old without bearing a child, will have nobody to draw water for her, i.e. will have nobody to help her.
M.equivalent: Children are poor men's riches.

M.proverb: Mutumia na kionje ni undu umwe.
M.translation: A woman and an invalid man are the same thing.
M.equivalent: Words for women, actions for men.

M.proverb: Mutumia ndaturaga mutwe na ndaikagia ndahi ndua.
M.translation: A woman does not split the head (of the slaughtered goat) nor dip the cup into the beer (because both are men's jobs).
M.equivalent: Let women spin and not preach.

M.translation: He that hands the hammer is not the same as the man who pulls the belows.
M.equivalent: You cannot drink and whistle at the same time.

M.translation: A blind man does not show another the way.
M.equivalent: Blind does not lead blind.

M.translation: He who carries an embassy has no concern in it.
M.equivalent: Messengers should neither be deheaded nor hanged.

M.translation: Only one head does not divide a field.
M.equivalent: Four eyes see more than two.

M.proverb: Mutwe wa mundu umwe ni ithino
M.translation: One man's head is a solitary place.
M.equivalent: Counsel is not of one.

M.translation: He who speaks does not know what others will reply.
He who travels sees great things.
M.equivalent: The world is a great book, of which they who never stir from home read only one page.

M.proverb: Muni kiriti niwe ui uria thina uigana wa migogo na nyamu
M.translation: It is the forest clearer who knows the troubles caused by trunks and animals.
M.equivalent: Every man knows his own business best.

M.proverb: Mumi na nja oyaga mara kana anyuaga twiri
M.translation: He that enters a hut either picks up the bowels or drinks twice.
M.note: To understand the proverb one must remember that the from the low front door. So people is being held may either be unlucky and instead of a piece of good meat, or may be drinks.

M.translation: It is they who have not died in war that start it.

M.proverb: Mwagi maguta oigaga hunyu ni umwe na maguta
M.translation: He that lacks fat says ugliness is the same as beauty.

M.proverb: Mwagi maguta oigaga ati king'aru ni undu umwe na maguta
M.translation: He who has no fat (to smear himself with) says that ochre is as good.
M.equivalent: 'Sour grapes,' as the fox said, when he could not reach them.

M.translation: Fire is not extinguished by fire.
M.equivalent: Fire is not to be quenched with tow.

M.translation: He that begins, is not he that finishes.
M.equivalent: Judge not of men or things at first sight.

M.translation: He who receives does not loathe.
M.equivalent: A gift horse is not looked in the mouth.

M.proverb: Mwana mukuru na ithe ni hamwe
M.translation: The eldest son and the father are one thing.
M.note: The proverb means that after the father's death the eldest son rules.

M.translation: Only the belly is a good (lucky) child (for its owner takes care of it and never lets it empty).
M.equivalent: The belly is the commanding part of the body.

M.translation: The son most loved (by his parents) does not know how to shake his feather head-dress.
M.note: The proverb alludes to the initiation rite, on which occasion a special head-dress composed of ostrich feathers is worn by thecandidates. It means that often the young man for whom the parents have bought a costly head-dress so that he may look well, does not show any gratitude by wearing it proudly.
M.equivalent: Things got easily are not appreciated.

M.translation: The child is not given away without a price.
M.note: The proverb is used especially by a father to the young man wanting to marry his daughter. It must be bourne in mind that the Kikuyu girl is not given to her husband, but she is bought by him.
M.equivalent: No gains without pains.

M.translation: The son is not beaten when the father is near.
The son need not ask his father for a piece of meat (for a parent spontaneously gives his children the best food).
A child who likes work does not lack one to wash him, i.e. to take care of him.
M.equivalent: God tempers the wind to the shorn lamb.

M.translation: The baby that has some one to take care for it does not dirty itself.
M.equivalent: Young and old age complete each other.

M.proverb: Mwana wa ndigwa niwe ui kwirera
M.translation: An orphan knows how to make shift with it (for he has nobody to help him).

M.proverb: Mwana wa ngari akunyaga ta nyina
M.translation: The baby leopard scratches like its mother.
M.equivalent: Like father, like son.

M.proverb: Mwana wa ngoriai ndekagira njingiri kuguru
M.translation: The orphan boy wears no rattles on his feet.
M.note: The Kikuyu used to wear rattles on their feet when dancing.

M.proverb: Mwana wa rwendo ariaga nyina na ithe
M.translation: The son of love eats his father and mother.
M.note: The proverb has the obvious meaning that the son who realizes he is his parent's Benjamin gives them most trouble. But it also means that the child born of illegitimate love will soon become a nuisance to his parents.
M.equivalent: To nourish a viper in one's bosom.

M.translation: The son of sin does not cease weeping.
M.equivalent: Sin and debts are always more than we think them to be.

M.proverb: Mwana wi na ithe ndanyuaga muma
M.translation: The son whose father is still alive, takes no oath (for his father defends him and if necessary, takes the oath instead of the son).
The youth is a part of the Divinity.
M.note: The proverb originates in the fact that the circumcised Kikuyu youth is greatly respected by women and uncircumcised young men.

M.translation: The youth who has enough to buy his girl, need not beseech her.
M.equivalent: Money is the sinew of love as well of war.

M.translation: He who airs something must air himself first.
M.equivalent: No gains without pains.

M.proverb: Mwari mwega ahitukira thome wa ngia
M.translation: Literal translation: A fair girl does not stop at a poor youth's (for he could not buy her).
One does not consult the witch-doctor about a white daughter.
M.note: It is luck for Kikuyu parents to have a daughter with skin whiter than the average. Such a girl will be sold dearer to her husband.

M.translation: He who talks about others' affairs does not know his own.
A boy is not sent to collect the honey (for he does not know how to collect it).
M.equivalent: Every man does his own business best.

M.proverb: Mwatukiria ki? Aca no thumbi na ruhuho
M.translation: What have you that we have not? Nothing but 'thumbi' and wind.
M.note: 'Thumbi' is the piece of cloth or leather used to fasten ostrich and other birds' feathers around the head. The proverb means, 'There is no news'.

M.proverb: Mwathwo ni nda arugite mwatho ni ithe
M.translation: Being ruled by one's stomach is better than being ruled by one's father.
Good people are sucked.
M.equivalent: Cover yourself with honey and the flies will attack you.

M.translation: He that wants to become rich must till the earth.
M.equivalent: Sleeping foxes catch no poultry.

M.translation: e who wants papyrus-ashes burns papyrus.
M.note: Previous to the advent of Europeans, the Kikuyu used papyrus-ashes, which are supposed to be rich in sodium, for cooking purposes.
M.equivalent: Let him that is cold blow coal.

M.proverb: Mwendi muhiriga utuikane etagia rurimi na mbere ndaruriaga
M.translation: He who wants to cause disagreement within the clan asks for the tongue (of the slaughtered goat) which he was not wont to eat before.
M.note: The tongue of the goat is a choice morsel which belongs by right to the head of the family or clan. The proverb means that he who wants a pretext for quarrelling, asks for somethingwhich he cannot be given.

M.translation: He who seeks evil finds it.
He who wants beauty does not complain (if it costs him some pain)
M.equivalent: No gains without pains.

M.translation: He who sells buys.
M.equivalent: To buy and to sell are both business.

M.translation: He who is loved receives no refusal.
The barber who shaves badly does not know any other (better) way of shaving.
M.equivalent: The first degree of folly is to think himself wise, the second is to tell others so, the third is to despise all counsel.

M.translation: The good millet is known at harvest time.
M.equivalent: A tree is known by its fruit.

M.translation: He who waits gets the best food, i.e. the biggest potato, the sweetest maize, etc. and can eat better cooked food.
He who wants to dig out a potato does not use a blunt pole.
M.note: The proverb means that he who wants to accomplish something, uses just those means that ensure success.

M.translation: The frog that compared itself to the ox lost its buttocks.
M.note: There is a fable, that the frog seeing what big buttocks the ox had, thought it could grow as big by swelling. But it burst and so lost buttocks and life.
M.equivalent: All covet, all lose.

M.proverb: Mwigerero wa ngoro ndukinyaga no wa Ngai ukinyaga
M.translation: What a man wants does not reach the goal, only what God wants reaches it.
M.equivalent: Man proposes, God disposes.

M.translation: Self defence is not fear.
M.equivalent: Weapons bode peace.

M.translation: To obtain what one wants is not a month's job.
M.equivalent: Time and straw make medlars ripe.

M.translation: He who lives alone has no quarrel.
M.equivalent: It takes two to make a quarrel.

M.translation: He who looks after his own business has no trouble.
He who has no patience will have no hard yams.
M.note: Yams are fully ripe only when they have grown hard. So he who wants to eat a good yam must be patient and wait till it is hard.
M.equivalent: Everything is good in its season.

M.proverb: Mwiri ti icoya ati ni ugutembuka
M.translation: One's body is not a banana leaf which should be rent.
M.equivalent: The proverb is told to people who threaten to abuse or have abused others.

M.translation: He who revenges himself is bad.
M.equivalent: In taking revenge a man is but even with his enemy; but in passing it over he is superior.

M.translation: He who takes counsel only from himself meets no hatred.

M.proverb: Mwithinia ndathinukaga, no muthinio ni athunukaga
M.translation: He who is the cause of his own troubles never comes to the end of them; but he who is troubled by others does.
He who sees today does not see tomorrow.
M.equivalent: Today thee, tomorrow me.

N.translation: Haste, before the trunk bridge becomes slippery
N.note: It must be borne in mind that native bridges consist of only one trunk spanning the two banks of the river. Hence passing such bridges in wet weather is dangerous.

N.proverb: Nda imwe yumaga muici na murogi
N.translation: The same womb gives birth to a thief and a poisoner.
The belly is more important than war.
The belly is not a head.
N.note: Into the head you can put as many things as you know without filling it, but you cannot do the same with your belly.

N.translation: I gave you the beauty of a guinea fowl and you give me the beauty of a francolin.
N.note: The proverb originates in the following fable. Once upon a time the guinea fowl wanting to dance, called upon the francolin to have its feathers dressed. The francolin, hoping to have the same favour returned by the guinea fowl, assented. But the latter taking as an excuse of its laziness that the dance was about to begin, left the other bird in the lurch. This is why the guinea fowl has now got much finer plumage than the francolin.
N.equivalent: To do good to the ungrateful is to throw rose-water into the sea.

N.proverb: Ndaregirwo ni ikere ta njagathi ikiregwo ni guoya
N.translation: I have no calves as lizards have got no hair.
N.note: Well shaped calves are supposed by the Kikuyu to add a great deal to one's beauty: therefore they are much appreciated.
N.equivalent: As poor as a church mouse.

N.translation: The long road arrives (at the goal).
N.note: The proverb means that a long but sure way, is better than a short but dangerous one.
N.equivalent: Fair and softly goes far in a day.

N.proverb: Ndegwa nyinyi ihaicaga ng'ombe na mutwe
N.translation: The young bull mounts the cows from the head.
N.equivalent: Young is the goose that will not eat oats.

N.translation: Sentences do not curdle like milk.
N.equivalent: Words and feathers are tossed by the wind.

N.translation: Good words are those spoken of common accord.
N.equivalent: Friendship is friendship and business is business' and 'A word is enough to the wise'.

N.translation: The animal that eats slowly can swalllow well.
N.equivalent: He that goes softly, goes safely.

N.translation: Nobody is forced to build his hut on the pattern of his 'wakini'.
N.note: 'Wakini' is a person circumcised at the same time-- somebody of the same age-group.
N.equivalent: Every one to his own taste.

N.translation: The thief does not tread on dry leaves (for they would betray his presence).
The bee does not begin with the comb.
N.equivalent: A good beginning makes a good ending.

N.proverb: Ndigure: Konyu kegura ni komirie ikwa
N.translation: Humble yourself: the inhabitants of Konyu were able to grow yams after humbling themselves.
N.note: The proverb originates in the legend that the people of Konyu, a place in the Kikuyu country, who had been at war with their neighbours of Mathira, ceased to be raided and could till their fields in peace, only by submitting.
N.equivalent: He makes a good war that makes good peace.

N.translation: The ox does not become old with strong muscles.
N.note: The proverb means that man cannot expect to age and retain the vigour of his youth.

N.translation: The mortar is not filled with juice in the place where it is rolled.
N.note: The proverb means that anything is found useful only in that place and by those people who are in need of it.
N.equivalent: Everything is good in its own season.

N.proverb: Ndiri njega ndiringanaga na muthi mwega
N.translation: A good mortar never meets a good pestle.
N.note: The proverb means that a good wife rarely meets a good husband and vice versa.

N.translation: Still water has finished many men.
N.equivalent: Beware of a silent dog and silent water.

N.translation: I do not want you to stick on to me like beard moss (sticks on the tree).
N.equivalent: Live and let live.

N.translation: I do not hate him who sees me so much as him who reveals me, i.e. my faults.
N.equivalent: Nobody is willing to acknowledge he is in fault.

N.proverb: Nditiku na magumi, o kuria mugaitanirira
N.translation: Nditiku and Magumi (go) to the place where you can agree.
N.note: Nditiku and Magumi are metaphorical names used to mean two quarrelsome people. The proverb is told to disagreeable people, who though warned do not stop their strife.
N.equivalent: He that cuts himself willingly deserves no balsam.

N.translation: It is not the meagre (but the fat) ox that breaks its leg.
N.equivalent: Misfortunes seldom come alone.

N.translation: A rich evil-doer is worse than a miser
One rich man cannto close the ford; i.e. cannot do all he would.
N.equivalent: No living man all things can.

N.translation: Do not give your foot the position which 'Nyakinua' gives.
N.note: 'Nyakinyua' is used to mean old women, who often sit unbecomingly.

N.translation: Every little hole of the ear has its little thorn.
N.note: The Kikuyu used to put little sticks or thorns in the pierced upper part of the ear.
N.equivalent: Every sparrow to its ear of wheat.

N.translation: Do not torment yourself as you torment the seeds of the broom-tree
Friendship begins with meeting at the road.
Friendship is steps, i.e. it consists in going to see one  another.
N.equivalent: Friendship consists in visiting friends.

N.translation: Many friends make one's pocket empty.
N.equivalent: Friends are pick-pockets.

N.proverb: Ndugu ya mwana imatagio ni nyina
N.translation: The friendship of the son is strengthened by his mother.
N.equivalent: Children's joys are parents' toys.

N.translation: I live alone like a poisoner.
N.note: The proverb illustrates the Kikuyu's dislike for poisoners and wizards.

N.translation: I live on saliva like a flea.
N.equivalent: To live from hand to mouth.

N.translation: Do not compare death with sleep (because they are not the same).
Do not make home affairs known.
N.equivalent: Do not wash dirty linen in public.

N.translation: Do not finish the small 'nduma'.
N.note: 'Nduma are the tubers of an edible arum much cultivated in Kikuyu. The proverb means that one must dig out only the big tubers and leave the small ones to grow new plants.
N.equivalent: Enjoy the present but think also of the future.

N.translation: Do not follow me as the 'njuu' follows the locusts.
N.note: 'Njuu' is the name of a kind of passerine bird, which follows locusts to feed on them.
N.equivalent: God deliver you from a false friend.

N.translation: The 'ndura' gives forth nothing but thorns.
N.note: 'Ndura' is the name of a thorny tree.
N.equivalent: One cannot gather figs from thistles.

N.translation: Darkness shows no wrong path to him who gets what he wants before dark.
N.equivalent: Early to bed, early to rise, make a man healthy, wealthy and wise.

N.translation: A blind man does not show another blind man the way.
N.equivalent: Do the blind lead the blind? Do they not both fall into the ditch?

N.proverb: Ndundu ya mwana na nyina ndiringagiririo
N.translation: It is not fair to attempt to penetrate mother and son's secrets.
Two noisy waterfalls cannot agree (in their tune).
N.equivalent: Two of a trade seldom agree.

N.translation: The turtle-dove coos when it has seen its nest
N.equivalent: Every bird likes its own nest best.

N.translation: It is the hyena that howls.
N.note: The proverb is applied to boisterous people.
N.equivalent: Barking dogs seldom bite.

N.translation: One can sing the song which precedes the circumcission and not be circumcissed.
N.equivalent: Man proposes, God disposes.

N.proverb: Ni muiguanite ta gikwa na mukungugu
N.translation: You agree like the yam and the tree to which it clings.
N.equivalent: to be like David and Jonathan

N.translation: Somebody may come in higher in dignity than he who was firstly invited.
N.note: The proverb has almost the same meaning as the words of the Gospel: When thou art invited to a wedding sit not down in the first seats at the table, lest perhaps one more honourable than thou be invited by him'; etc.
N.equivalent: Humility often gains more than pride.

N.proverb: Ni ngingo itindaga iri theri ti nda
N.translation: It is the neck that stays without ornament, but not the belly (without food).
The 'ngaita' is not eaten unless there is a reason.
N.note: 'Ngaita' is the very bitter fruit of a shrub, which is taken as an antihelmintic.
N.equivalent: Medicines are not meat to live on.

N.proverb: Ng'aragu ya mundu ungi ndingigiria ngome
N.translation: Other people's hunger does not hinder me from sleeping.
Arguments are the source of strifes.
N.equivalent: It takes two to make a quarrel.

N.translation: Discord breeds scorn.

N.proverb: Ngari ndioi gukunya ni kuonio yonirio
N.translation: The leopard did not know how to seize its prey: it was taught.
N.note: The Kikuyu say that when the leopard began to kill goats, it did not know how to seize them to kill. One day frightened by the shepherd, it had to leave its prey badly wounded though not killed. From the tree where it had taken refuge it heard the shepherd say: What luck! Had my goat been seized by the neck, it would be already dead'.

N.translation: One kindness prepares for another.
N.equivalent: One good turn deserves another.

N.translation: When lions have gone, hyenas dance.
N.equivalent: When the cat is away, the mice will play.

N.translation: The woman's trills are shouted at the mortar.
N.equivalent: Everything has its time.

N.translation: The animal that treads on the earth may find its trapper.
N.equivalent: To err is human

N.translation: The poor and the thorn do not sleep.
N.note: The former, say the Kikuyu, is kept awake by his anxieties whilst the latter is always on the alert in order to sting anyone who happens to touch it.
N.equivalent: Poverty breeds strife.

N.translation: The poor man is robbed even of his awl.
N.equivalent: The poor man turns his cake, and another comes and takes it away.

N.translation: One fly spoils an ox-hide.
N.equivalent: A little leak will sink a great ship.

N.translation: The fly has no sinew.
N.equivalent: You cannot make a silk purse from a sow's ear.

N.proverb: Ngi irahtagwo uigana mukiha uria iri naguo.
N.translation: The fly is bled proportionately to its veins.
N.equivalent: If you squeeze a cork, you will get but little juice.

N.translation: The neck does not grow above the head.
N.equivalent: Everything to its place.

N.proverb: Ngingo ya muria-ng'uru ni githitu na rurigi
N.translation: The neck of him who sells too dear, is all amulets and necklaces (for nobody buys from him).
N.equivalent: All covet, all lose.

N.translation: Oxen are not found through laziness.
N.equivalent: Laziness travels so slowly that poverty soon overtakes it.

N.translation: When the cow is left to the care of a man who is not the owner, the calves are suckled only when they cry.
N.equivalent: Look to the cow, the sow, and the wheat mow, and all will be well now.

N.translation: The heart eats what it likes.
N.equivalent: Love is blind.

N.proverb: Ngoro ni muru wa nyina na mundu
N.translation: Every man's brother is his heart.
N.equivalent: Few hearts that are not double, few tongues that are not cloves.

O.proverb: Ngoro ni muru wa nyina na mundu
O.equivalent: Few hearts that are not double, few tongues that are not cloves.
